sequence.notes: The reactant is propyne (3 carbons). The product is (E)-3-ethyl-2-iodobut-2-ene (5 carbons, 1 iodine). This transformation involves the addition of an ethyl group and an iodine atom across the alkyne. However, the regioselectivity implied by the drawn product (addition of ethyl to terminal carbon, and iodine replacing the other metal on the internal carbon, or a different alkyne) appears inconsistent with the typical regioselectivity of Zr-catalyzed carboalumination of terminal alkynes (which would typically place the ethyl group on the internal carbon and the Al-moiety on the terminal carbon).
Negishi cross-coupling of an (E)-vinyl iodide with an in-situ generated organozinc reagent from a terminal iodoalkyne.
Desilylation of a TMS-protected alkyne under basic conditions.

sequence.reaction_type: Hydrozirconation-iodination (via Negishi reagent, zirconocene dichloride and trimethylaluminum)
sequence.notes: Terminal alkyne is converted to a (Z)-trisubstituted vinyl iodide. The existing E-alkene remains unchanged.

A vinyl iodide undergoes lithium-halogen exchange with t-BuLi, followed by reaction with chloromethylboronic acid pinacol ester (ClCH2Bpin). This sequence results in a one-carbon homologation and the formation of a new carbon-boron bond, converting the vinyl iodide to a vinyl boronate. The first alkene remains unchanged (tetrasubstituted, no stereochemistry shown), while the E-stereochemistry of the second alkene is preserved.
Chiral auxiliary mediated stereoselective addition of a methyl group and subsequent allylic borylation.

Stereoselective addition of a methyl group adjacent to an existing chiral center, transforming an allylic boronic ester into a 1,2-disubstituted boronic ester. The two newly formed chiral centers are anti to each other.
Bpin group is replaced by a vinyl group. Stereochemistry of chiral centers and double bonds is retained.

Terminal alkene is converted to a primary alcohol (anti-Markovnikov hydration). Stereochemistry of existing double bonds and chiral centers is preserved. Reaction occurred in 2 steps, indicated by the yield statement.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using PDC.
